title: Absolutely simple group
summary: In mathematics, in the field of group theory, a group is said to be absolutely simple if it has no proper nontrivial serial subgroups.[1] That is, G {\displaystyle G} is an absolutely simple group if the only serial subgroups of G {\displaystyle G} are { e } {\displaystyle \{e\}} (the trivial subgroup), and G {\displaystyle G} itself (the whole group).
